optcom.domain module¶

class optcom.domain.Domain(bits=1, bit_width=100.0, samples_per_bit=512, memory_storage=1.0, noise_range=900.0, 1600.0, noise_samples=250)¶

Bases: object

Contain shared information about fields propagating in the same layout. Contain static methods for main physics variable conversion.

bits¶

Number of bits to consider.

Type

int

samples¶

Total number of samples per signal.

Type

int

time¶

Absolute time values for any signal. \([ps]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

dtime¶

The time step size. \([ps]\)

Type

float

time_window¶

The time window. \([ps]\)

Type

float

omega¶

Absolute angular frequency values for any signal. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

The angular frequency step size. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

float

omega_window¶

The angular frequency window. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

float

Absolute frequency values for any signal. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

dnu¶

The frequency step size. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

float

nu_window¶

The frequency window. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

float

noise_samples¶

The number of samples in the noise wavelength range.

noise_domega¶

The angular frequency step size of the noise. \([ps^{-1}]\)

noise_omega_window¶

The angular frequency window of the noise. \([ps^{-1}]\)

noise_omega¶

The angular frequency values of the noise \([ps^{-1}]\)

Parameters

  • bits -- Number of bits to consider.

  • bit_width -- The width of one bit. \([ps]\)

  • samples_per_bit -- Number of samples per bit.

  • memory_storage -- Max memory available if recording all steps of computation. Will be used if the attribute save_all of AbstractComponent is True. \([Gb]\)

  • noise_range -- The wavelength range in which the noise must be considered. \([nm]\)

  • noise_samples -- The number of samples in the noise wavelength range.

optcom.field module¶

class optcom.field.Field(domain, type, name='Field')¶

Bases: object

Represent a field made of several channels. At each channel is associated a delay, a repetition frequency and a center omega. A field is associated with one noise array. The channels and noise characteristics must be consistent the provided domain. This is to ensure consistency between all fields propagating in the layout sharing equivalent domains. N.B. 1 : please pay attention that the in-built operator __eq__ is overwritten, i.e. 'neq', 'not in', 'in', 'eq' operators are depending on the overwritten definition. N.B. 2 : A field can contain different channels center at the same angular frequencies and having the same repetition frequency, however, most of the Field methods will assume that each tuple of angular frequency and repetition frequency is unique. (e.g. math operators overload).

type¶

The type of the fields. See optcom/utils/constant_values/field_types.

Type

str

name¶

The name of the field.

Type

str

Parameters

  • domain (optcom.domain.Domain) -- The domain which the field is bound to.

  • type -- The type of the fields. See optcom/utils/constant_values/field_types.

  • name -- The name of the field.

add_delay(delays)¶
append(channel, center_omega, rep_freq, delay=0.0)¶

Append a channel to the field. The channel must comply with the field characteristics.

static average_power(A, dpos, rep_freq)¶
Parameters

  • A -- Pulse field envelope.

  • dpos -- The step interval. \([ps]\) if dtime, \([ps^{-1}]\) if omega.

  • rep_freq -- The repetition frequency. \([THz]\)

Returns

The average power of the pulse. \([W]\)

Notes

Equations:

\[P_{avg} = \frac{1}{T} \int_0^T P(t)\, dt = \frac{E_{pulse}}{T} = E_{pulse} f_{rep}\]

where \(E_{pulse}\) is the energy of the pulse, \(T\) is the pulse period and \(f_{rep}\) is the repetition frequency.

Implementation:

If \(f_{rep}=0\): (i.e. no repetition frequency specified by the user)

\[P_{avg} = 0\]

If \(f_{rep}=Nan\): (i.e. it is a CW pulse)

\[P_{avg} = \frac{1}{N_t}\sum_{t=0}^{N_t -1} P^t(A(t))\]

where \(N_t\) is the number of time samples and \(P^t\) depicts the temporal power.

If \(f_{rep} > 0\): (i.e. no repetition frequency specified by the user)

\[P_{avg} = E(A) f_{rep} = f_{rep}\Delta t\sum_{t=0}^{N_t -1}P^t(A(t))\]

where \(\Delta t\) is the time represented by one time sample, \(N_t\) is the number of time samples and \(P^t\) depicts the temporal power.

property center_omega¶
property channels¶
property delays¶
property domain¶
static energy(A, dpos)¶
Parameters

  • A -- Pulse field envelope.

  • dpos -- The step interval. \([ps]\) if dtime, \([ps^{-1}]\) if omega.

Returns

The energy of the pulse. \([J]\)

Notes

Equations:

\[E_{pulse} = \int_0^T P(t)\, dt\]

Implementation:

\[E(A) = \Delta t\sum_{t=0}^{N_t -1}P^t(A(t))\]

where \(\Delta t\) is the time represented by one time sample, \(N_t\) is the number of time samples and \(P^t\) depicts the temporal power.

operator_or_extend(operator, field_operand)¶

Execute the operation 'operator' between current Field and field operand for their common channels. The channels of field operand which do not have corresponding channels in the current field will be added to it.

Parameters

  • operator -- An operator name, must be a valid name from python operator module.

  • field_operand (optcom.field.Field) -- The operand of the operator (must be a Field).

Parameters

Returns

The spectral peak power of the pulse. \([a.u.]\)

Notes

\[P_{peak} = \underset{\lambda}{\max} \quad P^\lambda(A(t))\]

where \(P^\lambda\) depicts the spectral power.

class optcom.layout.Layout(domain=<optcom.domain.Domain object>, name='Layout')¶

Bases: object

Represent an optical system.

The layout is represented as a graph, i.e. set of components linked together by either unidirectionnal or bidirectionnal edges. The components contain the information on their neighbors, i.e. to which components and ports they are linked to.

domain¶

The domain which the layout is bound to.

Type

optcom.domain.Domain

name¶

The name of the Layout.

Type

str

Parameters

  • domain (optcom.domain.Domain) -- The domain which the layout is bound to.

  • name -- The name of the layout.

add_comp(*comps)¶

Add a component in the Layout.

Parameters

comps (AbstractComponent) -- A series of components to be added.

del_link(*links)¶

Delete a series of edges in the Layout.

Parameters

links -- Each tuple of the list contains the ports of the link to be deleted.

Parameters

Degree of the component given as parameter.

Module contents¶

class optcom.CW(name='CW', channels=1, center_lambda=[1552.0], peak_power=[0.001], energy=[], offset_nu=[0.0], init_phi=[0.0], field_name='', save=False, pre_call_code='', post_call_code='')¶

Bases: optcom.components.abstract_start_comp.AbstractStartComp

A CW pulse Generator.

name¶

The name of the component.

Type

str

ports_type¶

Type of each port of the component, give also the number of ports in the component. For types, see optcom/utils/constant_values/port_types.

Type

list of int

save¶

If True, will save each field going through each port. The recorded fields can be accessed with the attribute fields.

Type

bool

call_counter¶

Count the number of times the function __call__() of the Component has been called.

Type

int

wait¶

If True, will wait for specified waiting port policy added with the function AbstractComponent.add_wait_policy().

pre_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

post_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

channels¶

The number of channels in the field.

Type

int

center_lambda¶

The center wavelength of the channels. \([nm]\)

Type

list of float

peak_power¶

Peak power of the pulses. \([W]\)

Type

list of float

energy¶

Total power of the pulses. \([J]\) (peak_power will be ignored if energy provided)

offset_nu¶

The offset frequency. \([THz]\)

Type

list of float

init_phi¶

The nitial phase of the pulses.

Type

list of float

field_name¶

The name of the field.

Notes

\[A(0,t) = \sqrt{P_0} \exp\Big[i\big(\phi_0 - 2\pi (\nu_c +\nu_{offset})t\big)\Big]\]

Component diagram:

__________________ [0]
Parameters

  • name -- The name of the component.

  • channels -- The number of channels in the field.

  • center_lambda -- The center wavelength of the channels. \([nm]\)

  • peak_power -- Peak power of the pulses. \([W]\)

  • energy -- Total power of the pulses. \([J]\) (peak_power will be ignored if energy provided)

  • offset_nu -- The offset frequency. \([THz]\)

  • init_phi -- The initial phase of the pulses.

  • field_name -- The name of the field.

  • save -- If True, the last wave to enter/exit a port will be saved.

  • pre_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

  • post_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

property energy¶
class optcom.Fiber(name='Fiber', length=1.0, alpha=None, alpha_order=0, beta=None, beta_order=2, gamma=None, sigma=2.0, eta=2.0, T_R=0.003, h_R=None, f_R=0.245, core_radius=5.0, clad_radius=12.5, n_core=None, n_clad=None, NA=None, v_nbr=None, eff_area=None, nl_index=None, nl_approx=True, medium_core='sio2', medium_clad='sio2', temperature=293.1, ATT=True, DISP=True, SPM=True, XPM=False, FWM=False, SS=False, RS=False, XNL=False, NOISE=True, approx_type=1, noise_ode_method='rk4', UNI_OMEGA=True, STEP_UPDATE=False, INTRA_COMP_DELAY=True, INTRA_PORT_DELAY=True, INTER_PORT_DELAY=False, nlse_method='rk4ip', step_method='fixed', steps=100, save=False, save_all=False, max_nbr_pass=None, pre_call_code='', post_call_code='')¶

A non ideal Fiber.

name¶

The name of the component.

ports_type¶

save¶

If True, will save each field going through each port. The recorded fields can be accessed with the attribute fields.

Type

bool

call_counter¶

Count the number of times the function __call__() of the Component has been called.

Type

int

wait¶

If True, will wait for specified waiting port policy added with the function AbstractComponent.add_wait_policy().

pre_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

post_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

Notes

Component diagram:

[0] __________________ [1]
Parameters

  • name -- The name of the component.

  • length -- The length of the fiber. \([km]\)

  • alpha -- The derivatives of the attenuation coefficients. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • alpha_order -- The order of alpha coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if alpha values are provided - no file)

  • beta -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_order -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • gamma -- The non linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • sigma -- Positive term multiplying the XPM terms of the NLSE.

  • eta -- Positive term multiplying the cross-non-linear terms of the NLSE.

  • T_R -- The raman coefficient. \([]\)

  • h_R -- The Raman response function values. If a callable is provided, variable must be time. \([ps]\)

  • f_R -- The fractional contribution of the delayed Raman response. \([]\)

  • core_radius -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

  • clad_radius -- The radius of the cladding. \([\mu m]\)

  • n_core -- The refractive index of the core. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • n_clad -- The refractive index of the clading. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • NA -- The numerical aperture. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • v_nbr -- The V number. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • eff_area -- The effective area. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • nl_index -- The non-linear coefficient. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • nl_approx -- If True, the approximation of the NLSE is used.

  • medium_core -- The medium of the fiber core.

  • medium_clad -- The medium of the fiber cladding.

  • temperature -- The temperature of the fiber. \([K]\)

  • ATT -- If True, trigger the attenuation.

  • DISP -- If True, trigger the dispersion.

  • SPM -- If True, trigger the self-phase modulation.

  • XPM -- If True, trigger the cross-phase modulation.

  • FWM -- If True, trigger the Four-Wave mixing.

  • SS (bool) -- If True, trigger the self-steepening.

  • RS -- If True, trigger the Raman scattering.

  • XNL -- If True, trigger cross-non linear effects.

  • approx_type -- The type of the NLSE approximation.

  • NOISE -- If True, trigger the noise calculation.

  • noise_ode_method -- The ode solver method type for noise propagation computation.

  • UNI_OMEGA -- If True, consider only the center omega for computation. Otherwise, considered omega discretization.

  • STEP_UPDATE -- If True, update fiber parameters at each spatial sub-step.

  • INTRA_COMP_DELAY -- If True, take into account the relative time difference, between all waves, that is acquired while propagating in the component.

  • INTRA_PORT_DELAY -- If True, take into account the initial relative time difference between channels of all fields but for each port.

  • INTER_PORT_DELAY -- If True, take into account the initial relative time difference between channels of all fields of all ports.

  • nlse_method -- The nlse solver method type.

  • step_method -- The method for spatial step size generation.

  • steps -- The number of steps for the solver

  • save -- If True, the last wave to enter/exit a port will be saved.

  • save_all -- If True, save the wave at each spatial step in the component.

  • max_nbr_pass -- No fields will be propagated if the number of fields which passed through a specific port exceed the specified maximum number of pass for this port.

  • pre_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

  • post_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

class optcom.FiberYb(name='Ytterbium Fiber', length=1.0, alpha=[None], alpha_order=0, beta=[None], beta_order=2, gain_order=0, gamma=[None], sigma=2.0, eta=2.0, T_R=0.003, h_R=None, f_R=0.245, n_core=[None], n_clad=[None], NA=[None], v_nbr=[None], eff_area=[None], nl_index=[None], overlap=[None], sigma_a=[None], sigma_e=[None], en_sat=[None], doped_area=None, tau=840.0, N_T=0.063, core_radius=5.0, clad_radius=12.5, R_0=0.0008, R_L=0.0008, medium_core='sio2', medium_clad='sio2', temperature=293.1, nl_approx=True, RESO_INDEX=True, CORE_PUMPED=True, CLAD_PUMPED=False, ATT=[True, True], DISP=[True, False], SPM=[True, False], XPM=[False, False], FWM=[False, False], SS=[False, False], RS=[False, False], XNL=[False, False], GAIN_SAT=True, NOISE=True, approx_type=1, split_noise_option='seed_split', noise_ode_method='rk4', UNI_OMEGA=[True, True], STEP_UPDATE=False, INTRA_COMP_DELAY=True, INTRA_PORT_DELAY=True, INTER_PORT_DELAY=False, REFL_SEED=False, REFL_PUMP=True, PRE_PUMP_PROP=False, nlse_method='rk4ip', step_method='fixed', steps=100, max_nbr_iter=100, error=0.01, PROP_PUMP=False, PROP_REFL=False, BISEED=False, BIPUMP=False, save=False, save_all=False, max_nbr_pass=None, pre_call_code='', post_call_code='')¶

If True, will wait for specified waiting port policy added with the function AbstractComponent.add_wait_policy().

A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

post_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

REFL_SEED¶

If True, take into account the reflected seed waves for computation.

Type

bool

REFL_PUMP¶

If True, take into account the reflected pump waves for computation.

Type

bool

PROP_PUMP¶

If True, the pump is propagated forward in the layout.

Type

bool

PROP_REFL¶

If True, the relfected fields are propagated in the layout as new fields.

Type

bool

BISEED¶

If True, waiting policy waits for seed at both ends.

Type

bool

BIPUMP¶

If True, waiting policy waits for pump at both ends.

Type

bool

population_levels¶

The population density of each level. \([nm^{-3}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

Notes

Component diagram:

[0] _____________________ [1]
    /                   \
   /                     \
[2]                       [3]

[0] and [1] : signal and [2] and [3] : pump

Parameters

  • name -- The name of the component.

  • length -- The length of the fiber. \([km]\)

  • alpha -- The derivatives of the attenuation coefficients. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • alpha_order -- The order of alpha coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if alpha values are provided - no file)

  • beta -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_order -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • gain_order -- The order of the gain coefficients to take into account.

  • gamma -- The non linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • sigma -- Positive term multiplying the XPM terms of the NLSE.

  • eta -- Positive term multiplying the cross-non-linear terms of the NLSE.

  • T_R -- The raman coefficient. \([]\)

  • h_R -- The Raman response function values. If a callable is provided, variable must be time. \([ps]\)

  • f_R -- The fractional contribution of the delayed Raman response. \([]\)

  • n_core -- The refractive index of the core. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\) (1<=len(n_core)<=2 for signal and pump)

  • n_clad -- The refractive index of the cladding. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\) (1<=len(n_clad)<=2 for signal and pump)

  • NA -- The numerical aperture. \([]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\) (1<=len(NA)<=2 for signal and pump)

  • v_nbr -- The V number. \([]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\) (1<=len(v_nbr)<=2 for signal and pump)

  • eff_area -- The effective area. \([\u m^2]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\) (1<=len(eff_area)<=2 for signal and pump)

  • nl_index -- The non-linear coefficient. \([m^2\cdot W^{-1}]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\) (1<=len(nl_index)<=2 for signal and pump)

  • overlap -- The overlap factor. \([]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\) (1<=len(overlap)<=2 for signal and pump)

  • sigma_a -- The absorption cross sections. \([nm^2]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\) (1<=len(sigma_a)<=2 for signal and pump)

  • sigma_e -- The emission cross sections. \([nm^2]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\) (1<=len(sigma_e)<=2 for signal and pump)

  • en_sat -- The saturation energy. \([J]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\) (1<=len(en_sat)<=2 for signal and pump)

  • doped_area -- The doped area. \([\mu m^2]\) If None, will be set to the core area.

  • tau -- The lifetime of the metastable level. \([\mu s]\)

  • N_T -- The total doping concentration. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • core_radius -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

  • clad_radius -- The radius of the cladding. \([\mu m]\)

  • R_0 -- The reflectivity at the fiber start. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • R_L -- The reflectivity at the fiber end. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • medium_core -- The medium of the core.

  • medium_clad -- The medium of the cladding.

  • temperature -- The temperature of the fiber. \([K]\)

  • nl_approx -- If True, the approximation of the NLSE is used.

  • RESO_INDEX -- If True, trigger the resonant refractive index which will be added to the core refractive index. To see the effect of the resonant index, the flag STEP_UPDATE must be set to True in order to update the dispersion coefficient at each space step depending on the resonant index at each space step.

  • CORE_PUMPED -- If True, there is dopant in the core.

  • CLAD_PUMPED -- If True, there is dopant in the cladding.

  • ATT -- If True, trigger the attenuation. The first element is related to the seed and the second to the pump.

  • DISP -- If True, trigger the dispersion. The first element is related to the seed and the second to the pump.

  • SPM -- If True, trigger the self-phase modulation. The first element is related to the seed and the second to the pump.

  • XPM -- If True, trigger the cross-phase modulation. The first element is related to the seed and the second to the pump.

  • FWM -- If True, trigger the Four-Wave mixing. The first element is related to the seed and the second to the pump.

  • SS -- If True, trigger the self-steepening. The first element is related to the seed and the second to the pump.

  • RS -- If True, trigger the Raman scattering. The first element is related to the seed and the second to the pump.

  • XNL -- If True, trigger cross-non linear effects. The first element is related to the seed and the second to the pump.

  • GAIN_SAT -- If True, trigger the gain saturation.

  • NOISE -- If True, trigger the noise calculation.

  • approx_type -- The type of the NLSE approximation.

  • split_noise_option -- The way the spontaneous emission power is split among the fields.

  • noise_ode_method -- The ode solver method type for noise propagation computation.

  • UNI_OMEGA -- If True, consider only the center omega for computation. Otherwise, considered omega discretization. The first element is related to the seed and the second to the pump.

  • STEP_UPDATE -- If True, update fiber parameters at each spatial sub-step.

  • INTRA_COMP_DELAY -- If True, take into account the relative time difference, between all waves, that is acquired while propagating in the component.

  • INTRA_PORT_DELAY -- If True, take into account the initial relative time difference between channels of all fields but for each port.

  • INTER_PORT_DELAY -- If True, take into account the initial relative time difference between channels of all fields of all ports.

  • REFL_SEED -- If True, take into account the reflected seed waves for computation.

  • REFL_PUMP -- If True, take into account the reflected pump waves for computation.

  • PRE_PUMP_PROP -- If True, propagate only the pump the first iteration and then add the seed at the second iteration. Otherwise, consider both pump and seed simultaneously. Results will be consistent but setting this flag to True can have a significant impact on the convergence speed. Without knowledge of the algorithm, it is adviced to let it to False.

  • nlse_method -- The nlse solver method type.

  • step_method -- The method for spatial step size generation.

  • steps -- The number of steps for the solver

  • max_nbr_iter -- The maximum number of iterations if shooting method is employed.

  • error -- The error for convergence criterion of stepper resolution.

  • PROP_PUMP -- If True, the pump is propagated forward in the layout.

  • PROP_REFL -- If True, the relfected fields are propagated in the layout as new fields.

  • BISEED -- If True, waiting policy waits for seed at both ends.

  • BIPUMP -- If True, waiting policy waits for pump at both ends.

  • save -- If True, the last wave to enter/exit a port will be saved.

  • save_all -- If True, save the wave at each spatial step in the component.

  • max_nbr_pass -- No fields will be propagated if the number of fields which passed through a specific port exceed the specified maximum number of pass for this port.

  • pre_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

  • post_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

class optcom.FiberCoupler(name='Fiber Coupler', length=1.0, nbr_fibers=2, alpha=[None], alpha_order=0, beta=[None], beta_order=2, gamma=[None], kappa=[[None]], sigma=[2.0], sigma_cross=[[0.0]], eta=[2.0], eta_cross=[[0.0]], T_R=[0.003], h_R=[None], f_R=0.245, core_radius=[5.0], clad_radius=62.5, c2c_spacing=[[15.0]], n_core=[None], n_clad=None, NA=[None], v_nbr=[None], eff_area=[None], nl_index=[None], nl_approx=True, medium_core=['sio2'], medium_clad='sio2', temperature=293.1, ATT=True, DISP=True, SPM=True, XPM=False, FWM=False, SS=False, RS=False, XNL=False, ASYM=True, COUP=True, NOISE=True, approx_type=1, noise_ode_method='rk4', UNI_OMEGA=True, STEP_UPDATE=False, INTRA_COMP_DELAY=True, INTRA_PORT_DELAY=True, INTER_PORT_DELAY=False, nlse_method='rk4ip', ode_method='euler', step_method='fixed', steps=100, save=False, save_all=False, wait=False, max_nbr_pass=None, pre_call_code='', post_call_code='')¶

           \______/

Parameters

  • name -- The name of the component.

  • length -- The length of the coupler. \([km]\)

  • nbr_fibers -- The number of fibers in the coupler.

  • alpha -- The derivatives of the attenuation coefficients. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • alpha_order -- The order of alpha coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if alpha values are provided - no file)

  • beta -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_order -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • gamma -- The non linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • kappa -- The coupling coefficients. \([km^{-1}]\)

  • sigma -- Positive term multiplying the XPM terms of the NLSE.

  • sigma_cross -- Positive term multiplying the XPM terms of the NLSE inbetween the fibers.

  • eta -- Positive term multiplying the cross-non-linear terms of the NLSE.

  • eta_cross -- Positive term multiplying the cross-non-linear terms of the NLSE inbetween the fibers.

  • T_R -- The raman coefficient. \([]\)

  • h_R -- The Raman response function values. If a callable is provided, variable must be time. \([ps]\)

  • f_R -- The fractional contribution of the delayed Raman response. \([]\)

  • core_radius -- The core radius. \([\mu m]\)

  • clad_radius -- The radius of the cladding. \([\mu m]\)

  • c2c_spacing -- The center to center distance between two cores. \([\mu m]\)

  • n_core -- The refractive index of the core. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • n_clad -- The refractive index of the clading. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • NA -- The numerical aperture. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • v_nbr -- The V number. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • eff_area -- The effective area. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • nl_index -- The non-linear coefficient. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • nl_approx -- If True, the approximation of the NLSE is used.

  • medium_core -- The medium of the fiber core.

  • medium_clad -- The medium of the fiber cladding.

  • temperature -- The temperature of the fiber. \([K]\)

  • ATT -- If True, trigger the attenuation.

  • DISP -- If True, trigger the dispersion.

  • SPM -- If True, trigger the self-phase modulation.

  • XPM -- If True, trigger the cross-phase modulation.

  • FWM -- If True, trigger the Four-Wave mixing.

  • SS (bool) -- If True, trigger the self-steepening.

  • RS -- If True, trigger the Raman scattering.

  • XNL -- If True, trigger cross-non linear effects.

  • ASYM -- If True, trigger the asymmetry effects between cores.

  • COUP -- If True, trigger the coupling effects between cores.

  • NOISE -- If True, trigger the noise calculation.

  • approx_type -- The type of the NLSE approximation.

  • noise_ode_method -- The ode solver method type for noise propagation computation.

  • UNI_OMEGA -- If True, consider only the center omega for computation. Otherwise, considered omega discretization.

  • STEP_UPDATE -- If True, update fiber parameters at each spatial sub-step.

  • INTRA_COMP_DELAY -- If True, take into account the relative time difference, between all waves, that is acquired while propagating in the component.

  • INTRA_PORT_DELAY -- If True, take into account the initial relative time difference between channels of all fields but for each port.

  • INTER_PORT_DELAY -- If True, take into account the initial relative time difference between channels of all fields of all ports.

  • nlse_method -- The nlse solver method type.

  • ode_method -- The ode solver method type.

  • step_method -- The method for spatial step size generation.

  • steps -- The number of steps for the solver

  • save -- If True, the last wave to enter/exit a port will be saved.

  • save_all -- If True, save the wave at each spatial step in the component.

  • wait -- If True, wait for another pulse in the anolog port [0 <-> 1, and 2 <-> 3] to launch the simulation.

  • max_nbr_pass -- No fields will be propagated if the number of fields which passed through a specific port exceed the specified maximum number of pass for this port.

  • pre_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

  • post_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

list of float

width¶

Half width of the pulse. \([ps]\)

Type

list of float

fwhm¶

Full band width at half maximum. \([ps]\) If fwhm is provided, the width will be ignored. If fwhm is not provided or set to None, will use the width.

Type

list of float, optional

peak_power¶

Peak power of the pulses. \([W]\)

Type

list of float

rep_freq¶

The repetition frequency of the pulse in the time window. \([THz]\)

offset_nu¶

The offset frequency. \([THz]\)

Type

list of float

order¶

The order of the super gaussian pulse.

Type

list of int

chirp¶

The chirp parameter for chirped pulses.

Type

list of float

init_phi¶

The initial phase of the pulses.

Type

list of float

noise¶

The initial noise along the pulses.

Type

np.ndarray

Notes

\[A(0,t) = \sqrt{P_0} \exp\bigg[-\frac{1+iC}{2} \bigg(\frac{t-t_0}{T_0}\bigg)^{2m} + i\big(\phi_0 - 2\pi (\nu_c + \nu_{offset})t\big)\bigg]\]

where \(t_0\) is the half width at \(1/e\)-intensity.

Component diagram:

__________________ [0]
Parameters

  • name -- The name of the component.

  • channels -- The number of channels in the field.

  • center_lambda -- The center wavelength of the channels. \([nm]\)

  • position -- Relative position of the pulses in the time window. \(\in [0,1]\)

  • width -- Half width of the pulse. \([ps]\)

  • fwhm -- Full band width at half maximum. \([ps]\) If fwhm is provided, the width will be ignored. If fwhm is not provided or set to None, will use the width.

  • peak_power -- Peak power of the pulses. \([W]\)

  • rep_freq -- The repetition frequency of the pulse in the time window. \([THz]\)

  • offset_nu -- The offset frequency. \([THz]\)

  • order -- The order of the super gaussian pulse.

  • chirp -- The chirp parameter for chirped pulses.

  • init_phi -- The initial phase of the pulses.

  • noise -- The initial noise along the pulses.

  • field_name -- The name of the field.

  • save -- If True, the last wave to enter/exit a port will be saved.

  • pre_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

  • post_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

class optcom.IdealCombiner(name='Ideal Combiner', arms=2, combine=False, ratios=[], wait=True, save=False, max_nbr_pass=None, pre_call_code='', post_call_code='')¶

Bases: optcom.components.abstract_pass_comp.AbstractPassComp

An ideal Combiner.

name¶

The name of the component.

Type

str

ports_type¶

Type of each port of the component, give also the number of ports in the component. For types, see optcom/utils/constant_values/port_types.

Type

list of int

save¶

If True, will save each field going through each port. The recorded fields can be accessed with the attribute fields.

Type

bool

call_counter¶

Count the number of times the function __call__() of the Component has been called.

Type

int

wait¶

If True, will wait for specified waiting port policy added with the function AbstractComponent.add_wait_policy().

pre_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

post_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

arms¶

The number of input arms.

Type

int

combine¶

If False, propagate all incoming fields in the last port. Otherwise, add common channels and append the others to create one single field. Both methods operate depending on ratios provided.

ratios¶

A list of ratios where each index is related to one arm. The length of the list should be equal to the number of arms, if not it will be pad to it. The ratio represents the fraction of the power that will be taken from the field arriving at the corresponding arm.

Notes

Component diagram:

[0]   _________
[1]   __________\
[2]   ___________\_______ [n]
[3]   ___________/
    ...
[n-1] _________/
Parameters

  • name -- The name of the component.

  • arms -- The number of input arms.

  • combine -- If False, propagate all incoming fields in the last port. Otherwise, add common channels and append the others to create one single field. Both methods operate depending on ratios provided.

  • ratios -- A list of ratios where each index is related to one arm. The length of the list should be equal to the number of arms, if not it will be pad to it. The ratio represents the fraction of the power that will be taken from the field arriving at the corresponding arm.

  • save -- If True, the last wave to enter/exit a port will be saved.

  • max_nbr_pass -- No fields will be propagated if the number of fields which passed through a specific port exceed the specified maximum number of pass for this port.

  • pre_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

  • post_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

ports_type¶

The number of input arms.

divide¶

If False, propagate a copy of entering fields to each output port. (ratios will be ignored) Otherwise, divide power depending on provided ratios.

Type

ratios¶

A list of ratios where each index is related to one arm. The length of the list should be equal to the number of arms, if not it will be pad to it. The ratio represents the fraction of the power that will be taken from the field arriving at the corresponding arm.

  • arms -- The number of input arms.

  • divide -- If False, propagate a copy of entering fields to each output port. (ratios will be ignored) Otherwise, divide power depending on provided ratios.

  • ratios -- A list of ratios where each index is related to one arm. The length of the list should be equal to the number of arms, if not it will be pad to it. The ratio represents the fraction of the power that will be taken from the field arriving at the corresponding arm.

class optcom.IdealMZM(name='Ideal MZ Modulator', phase_shift=[0.0, 0.0], loss=0.0, extinction=None, v_pi=None, v_bias=None, v_mod=None, save=False, max_nbr_pass=None, pre_call_code='', post_call_code='')¶

Bases: optcom.components.abstract_pass_comp.AbstractPassComp

An ideal Mach Zehnder Modulator

name¶

The name of the component.

Type

str

ports_type¶

phase_shift¶

The phase difference induced between the two arms of the MZ. Can be a list of callable with time variable. \([ps]\) (will be ignored if (v_pi and v_bias) or (v_pi and v_mod) are provided)

loss¶

The loss induced by the MZ. \([dB]\)

extinction¶

The extinction ratio. \([dB]\)

v_pi¶

The half-wave voltage. \([V]\)

v_bias¶

The bias voltage. \([V]\)

v_mod¶

The modulation voltage \([V]\). Must be a callable with time variable. \([ps]\)

Notes

\[\phi_k(t)= \pi \frac{V_{mod,k}(t)+V_{bias,k}}{V_{\pi,k}} \quad k\in\{1,2\}\]

  • loss -- The loss induced by the MZ. \([dB]\)

  • extinction -- The extinction ratio. \([dB]\)

  • v_pi -- The half-wave voltage. \([V]\)

  • v_bias -- The bias voltage. \([V]\)

  • v_mod -- The modulation voltage \([V]\). Must be a callable with time variable. \([ps]\)

class optcom.LoadFieldFromFile(name='Field File Loader', file_name='fields_saved', list_index_to_load=[], raise_type_error=True, save=False, pre_call_code='', post_call_code='')¶

Bases: optcom.components.abstract_start_comp.AbstractStartComp

This component allows one to load fields from a file which contains list of Field objects as a file line.

name¶

The name of the component.

Type

str

ports_type¶

Type of each port of the component, give also the number of ports in the component. For types, see optcom/utils/constant_values/port_types.

Type

list of int

save¶

If True, will save each field going through each port. The recorded fields can be accessed with the attribute fields.

Type

bool

call_counter¶

Count the number of times the function __call__() of the Component has been called.

Type

int

wait¶

If True, will wait for specified waiting port policy added with the function AbstractComponent.add_wait_policy().

pre_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

post_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

file_name¶

The name of the file in which the fields are saved.

Type

str

list_index_to_load¶

The indices of the fields from the loaded Field list to propagate. If the index is out of range, this index is ignore. If the list is empty, will propagate all fields.

raise_type_error¶

If True, raise an error if the type of the loaded object from file is not a list of Field. If False, ignore the object.

Notes

Component diagram:

__________________ [0]
Parameters

  • name -- The name of the component.

  • file_name -- The name of the file in which the fields are saved. Please specify full path to file folder if not saving in current directory. If no extension is provided, the default file extension will be considered. See config for default extension.

  • list_index_to_load -- The indices of the fields from the loaded Field list to propagate. If the index is out of range, this index is ignore. If the list is empty, will propagate all fields.

  • raise_type_error -- If True, raise an error if the type of the loaded object from file is not a list of Field. If False, ignore the object.

  • pre_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

  • post_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

class optcom.SaveFieldToFile(name='Field File Saver', file_name='fields_saved', add_fields=True, save=False, pre_call_code='', post_call_code='')¶

Bases: optcom.components.abstract_pass_comp.AbstractPassComp

This component allows one to save one or multiple field(s) into a file. Dump all simultaneous incoming fields to a list of fields as a new line in a pk1 file.

name¶

The name of the component.

Type

str

ports_type¶

Type of each port of the component, give also the number of ports in the component. For types, see optcom/utils/constant_values/port_types.

Type

list of int

save¶

If True, will save each field going through each port. The recorded fields can be accessed with the attribute fields.

Type

bool

call_counter¶

Count the number of times the function __call__() of the Component has been called.

Type

int

wait¶

If True, will wait for specified waiting port policy added with the function AbstractComponent.add_wait_policy().

pre_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

post_call_code¶

A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

file_name¶

The name of the file in which the fields are saved.

Type

str

add_fields¶

If True and the file_name provided exists, add fields if fields already in file_name.

Notes

Component diagram:

[0] __________________
Parameters

  • name -- The name of the component.

  • file_name -- The name of the file in which the fields are saved. Please specify full path to file folder if not saving in current directory. If no extension is provided, the default file extension will be considered. See config for default extension.

  • add_fields -- If True and the file_name provided exists, add fields if fields already in file_name.

  • pre_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed prior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters input_ports and input_fields are available.

  • post_call_code -- A string containing code which will be executed posterior to the call to the function __call__(). The two parameters output_ports and output_fields are available.

\[A(0,t) = \sqrt{P_0} \,\text{sech}\Big(\frac{t-t_0}{T_0} \Big)\exp\bigg[-\frac{iC}{2} \bigg(\frac{t-t_0}{T_0}\bigg)^{2} + i(\phi_0 - 2\pi (\nu_c + \nu_{offset})t)\bigg]\]

where \(t_0\) is the half width at \(1/e\)-intensity.

class optcom.Soliton(name='Soliton', channels=1, center_lambda=[1552.0], position=[0.5], width=[10.0], fwhm=None, rep_freq=[0.0], offset_nu=[0.0], order=[1], init_phi=[0.0], noise=None, beta_2=[- 18.0], gamma=[1.0], field_name='', save=False, pre_call_code='', post_call_code='')¶

Bases: optcom.components.abstract_start_comp.AbstractStartComp

A soliton pulse Generator.

name¶

The name of the component.

Type

str

Type of each port of the component, give also the number of ports in the component. For types, see optcom/utils/constant_values/port_types.

The number of channels in the field.

Type

int

The center wavelength of the channels. \([nm]\)

Type

list of float

Relative position of the pulses in the time window. \(\in [0,1]\)

Type

list of float

width¶

Half width of the pulse. \([ps]\)

Type

list of float

fwhm¶

Full band width at half maximum. \([ps]\) If fwhm is provided, the width will be ignored. If fwhm is not provided or set to None, will use the width.

Type

list of float, optional

rep_freq¶

The repetition frequency of the pulse in the time window. \([THz]\)

offset_nu¶

The offset frequency. \([THz]\)

Type

list of float

order¶

The order of the super soliton pulse.

Type

list of int

beta_2¶

The GVD term of the dispersion. (must be negative) \([ps^2\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Type

list of float

gamma¶

The non-linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Type

list of float

init_phi¶

The nitial phase of the pulses.

Type

list of float

noise¶

The initial noise along the pulses.

Type

np.ndarray

Notes

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} A(0,t) &= \sqrt{P_0}\,\text{sech}\Big(\frac{t-t_0}{T_0} \Big)\exp\bigg[i(\phi_0-2\pi(\nu_c +\nu_{offset})t)\bigg]\\ &= \sqrt{\frac{N_s^2}{\gamma L_D}} \,\text{sech}\Big(\frac{t-t_0}{T_0}\Big) \exp\bigg[i(\phi_0-2\pi(\nu_c+\nu_{offset})t) \bigg]\\ &= \sqrt{-\frac{N_s^2 \beta_2}{\gamma T_0^2}} \,\text{sech}\Big(\frac{t-t_0}{T_0}\Big) \exp\bigg[i(\phi_0-2\pi(\nu_c+\nu_{offset})t) \bigg] \end{split}\end{split}\]

where \(t_0\) is the half width at \(1/e\)-intensity.

  • channels -- The number of channels in the field.

  • width -- Half width of the pulse. \([ps]\)

  • fwhm -- Full band width at half maximum. \([ps]\) If fwhm is provided, the width will be ignored. If fwhm is not provided or set to None, will use the width.

  • rep_freq -- The repetition frequency of the pulse in the time window. \([THz]\)

  • offset_nu -- The offset frequency. \([THz]\)

  • init_phi -- The initial phase of the pulses.

  • noise -- The initial noise along the pulses.

  • beta_2 -- The GVD term of the dispersion. (must be negative) \([ps^2\cdot km^{-1}]\)

  • gamma -- The non-linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\)

class optcom.Layout(domain=<optcom.domain.Domain object>, name='Layout')¶

Bases: object

Represent an optical system.

The layout is represented as a graph, i.e. set of components linked together by either unidirectionnal or bidirectionnal edges. The components contain the information on their neighbors, i.e. to which components and ports they are linked to.

domain¶

The domain which the layout is bound to.

  • name -- The name of the layout.

optcom.energy(A, dpos)¶
Parameters

  • A -- Pulse field envelope.

  • dpos -- The step interval. \([ps]\) if dtime, \([ps^{-1}]\) if omega.

Returns

The energy of the pulse. \([J]\)

Notes

Equations:

\[E_{pulse} = \int_0^T P(t)\, dt\]

Implementation:

\[E(A) = \Delta t\sum_{t=0}^{N_t -1}P^t(A(t))\]

where \(\Delta t\) is the time represented by one time sample, \(N_t\) is the number of time samples and \(P^t\) depicts the temporal power.

optcom.average_power(A, dpos, rep_freq)¶
Parameters

  • A -- Pulse field envelope.

  • dpos -- The step interval. \([ps]\) if dtime, \([ps^{-1}]\) if omega.

  • rep_freq -- The repetition frequency. \([THz]\)

Returns

The average power of the pulse. \([W]\)

Notes

Equations:

\[P_{avg} = \frac{1}{T} \int_0^T P(t)\, dt = \frac{E_{pulse}}{T} = E_{pulse} f_{rep}\]

where \(E_{pulse}\) is the energy of the pulse, \(T\) is the pulse period and \(f_{rep}\) is the repetition frequency.

Implementation:

If \(f_{rep}=0\): (i.e. no repetition frequency specified by the user)

\[P_{avg} = 0\]

If \(f_{rep}=Nan\): (i.e. it is a CW pulse)

\[P_{avg} = \frac{1}{N_t}\sum_{t=0}^{N_t -1} P^t(A(t))\]

where \(N_t\) is the number of time samples and \(P^t\) depicts the temporal power.

If \(f_{rep} > 0\): (i.e. no repetition frequency specified by the user)

\[P_{avg} = E(A) f_{rep} = f_{rep}\Delta t\sum_{t=0}^{N_t -1}P^t(A(t))\]

where \(\Delta t\) is the time represented by one time sample, \(N_t\) is the number of time samples and \(P^t\) depicts the temporal power.

optcom.fwhm(A, dpos, peak_position=None)¶
Parameters

  • A -- Pulse field envelope.

  • dpos -- The step interval. \([ps]\) if dtime, \([ps^{-1}]\) if omega.

  • peak_position -- The position of the peak if not centered.

Returns

The average power of the pulse. \([W]\)

optcom.calc_dispersion_length(width, beta_2)¶

Calculate dispersion length.

  • beta_2 -- The GVD term of the dispersion. \([ps^2\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Returns

The dispersion length \([km]\)

Notes

\[L_{D} = \frac{T_0^2}{|\beta_2|}\]
optcom.calc_kappa(omega, v_nbr, a, d, ref_index)¶

Calculate the coupling coefficient for the parameters given for two waveguides. (assuming the two waveguides are symmetric) 3

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • v_nbr -- The fiber parameter.

  • a -- The core radius. \([\mu m]\)

  • d -- The center to center spacing between the two cores. \([\mu m]\)

  • ref_index -- The refractive index outside of the two fiber cores.

Returns

Value of the coupling coefficient. \([km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\kappa = \frac{\pi V}{2 k_0 n_0 a^2} e^{-(c_0 + c_1 d + c_2 d^2)}\]

This equation is accurate to within 1% for values of the fiber parameter \(1.5\leq V\leq 2.5\) and of the normalized center-to-center spacing \(\bar{d} = d/a\), \(2\leq \bar{d}\leq 4.5\) .

References

3

Govind Agrawal, Chapter 2: Fibers Couplers, Applications of Nonlinear Fiber Optics (Second Edition), Academic Press, 2008, Page 59.

optcom.calc_v_number(omega, NA, core_radius)¶

Calculate the V parameter.

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • NA -- The numerical aperture.

  • core_radius -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

Returns

Value of the V parameter.

Notes

Considering:

\[V = k_0 a \text{NA} = \frac{\omega_0}{c} a \text{NA}\]
class optcom.Sellmeier(medium='sio2', dopant='geo2', dopant_concent=0.0)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Sellmeier equations.

Represent the Sellmeier equations which are empirical relationship between refractive index and wavelength for a specific medium. 12

References

12

Malitson, I.H., 1965. Interspecimen comparison of the refractive index of fused silica. Josa, 55(10), pp.1205-1209.

Parameters

  • medium -- The medium in which the wave propagates.

  • dopant -- The dopant of the medium.

  • dopant_concent -- The concentration of the dopant. [mole%]

static calc_ref_index(omega, As, lambdas, dopant_slope=0.0, dopant_concent=0.0)¶

Compute the Sellmeier equations.

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • As -- The A coefficients for the sellmeier equations.

  • lambdas -- The wavelength coefficients for the sellmeier equations.

  • dopant_slope -- The slope coefficient of the dopant linear fitting.

  • dopant_concent -- The concentration of the dopant. [mole%]

Returns

The refractive index.

Notes

\[n^2(\lambda) = 1 + \sum_i A_i \frac{\lambda^2}{\lambda^2 - \lambda_i}\]

If dopant is specified, use linear fitting parameters from empirical data at 1300 nm.

\[n_{new}(\lambda, d) = n(\lambda) + a d\]

where \(a\) is the slope of the linear fitting and \(d\) is the dopant concentration.

optcom.calc_NA(n_core, n_clad)¶

Calculate the numerical aperture.

Parameters

  • n_core -- The refractive index of the core.

  • n_clad -- The refractive index of the cladding.

Returns

The numerical aperture.

Notes

\[NA = \sqrt{n_{co}^2 - n_{cl}^2}\]
optcom.calc_n_core(NA, n_clad)¶

Calculate the numerical aperture.

Parameters

  • NA -- The numerical aperture.

  • n_clad -- The refractive index of the cladding.

Returns

The refractive index of the core.

Notes

\[n_{co} = \sqrt{NA^2 + n_{cl}^2}\]
optcom.calc_n_clad(NA, n_core)¶

Calculate the numerical aperture.

Parameters

  • NA -- The numerical aperture.

  • n_core -- The refractive index of the core.

Returns

The refractive index of the cladding.

Notes

\[n_{cl} = \sqrt{n_{co}^2 - NA^2}\]
optcom.plot2d(x_datas, y_datas, x_labels=None, y_labels=None, x_ranges=None, y_ranges=None, plot_linestyles=['-'], plot_labels=None, plot_titles=None, plot_colors=None, plot_groups=None, split=False, opacity=[0.2], fig_title=None, filename='', resolution=1920.0, 1080.0, triangle_layout=False)¶

Plot an 2D graph.

Parameters

  • x_datas -- The data on the x axis.

  • y_datas -- The data on the y axis.

  • x_label -- The labels for each axis on each plot along the x axis.

  • y_label -- The labels for each axis on each plot along the y axis.

  • x_range -- The ranges for each axis on each plot along the x axis.

  • y_range -- The ranges for each axis on each plot along the y axis.

  • plot_linestyle -- The linestyle of the lines.

  • plot_labels -- The labels for each lines on each plot.

  • plot_titles -- The title of each plot.

  • plot_colors -- The color of each line on each plot.

  • plot_groups -- The group of each line. The line having the same number will be displayed on the plot.

  • split -- If True, split all the lines in one plote. If False, group all the lines in one plot. Only considered if plot_groups is None.

  • opacity -- The opacity of the lines.

  • fig_title -- The figure title.

  • filename -- The filename where to save the image. If provided, the animation will be saved.

  • resolution -- The resolution with which to save the image.

  • triangle_layout -- Option for 3 plots, if True, put the one wide plot at the bottom and the 2 other plots on the top.

optcom.plot3d(x_datas, y_datas, z_datas=None, x_labels=None, y_labels=None, z_labels=None, x_ranges=None, y_ranges=None, z_ranges=None, plot_titles=None, plot_colors=None, plot_groups=None, split=False, opacity=[0.8], fig_title=None, filename='', resolution=1920.0, 1080.0, plot_types=['plot_surface'], triangle_layout=False)¶

  • y_datas -- The data on the y axis.

  • z_datas -- The data on the z axis.

  • plot_labels -- The labels for each lines on each plot.

  • plot_titles -- The title of each plot.

  • plot_colors -- The color of each line on each plot.

  • plot_groups -- The group of each line. The line having the same number will be displayed on the plot.

optcom.animation2d(x_datas, y_datas, z_datas=None, x_label=None, y_label=None, x_range=None, y_range=None, plot_linestyle='-', plot_linewidth=1.0, plot_labels=None, plot_title=None, plot_colors=None, opacity=0.2, fig_title=None, filename='', resolution=1920.0, 1080.0, interval=100.0, repeat=True, repeat_delay=1000.0)¶

Plot an 2D animation.

Parameters

  • x_datas -- The data on the x axis.

  • y_datas -- The data on the y axis.

  • z_datas -- The data on the z axis.

  • x_label -- The labels for each axis along the x axis.

  • y_label -- The labels for each axis along the y axis.

  • x_range -- The ranges for each axis along the x axis.

  • y_range -- The ranges for each axis along the y axis.

  • plot_linestyle -- The linestyle of the lines.

  • plot_linewidth -- The linewidth of the lines.

  • plot_labels -- The labels for each lines.

  • plot_title -- The title of the animation.

  • plot_colors -- The color of each line.

  • opacity -- The opacity of the lines.

  • fig_title -- The figure title.

  • filename -- The filename where to save the animation. If provided, the animation will be saved.

  • resolution -- The resolution with which to save the animation.

  • interval -- The interval in between each frame.

  • repeat -- Either to repeat the animation when it is displayed.

  • repeat_delay -- The delay in between each repetition.

class optcom.AbsorptionSection(dopant='yb', medium='sio2', T=293.1, sigma_e=None)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • dopant -- The doping medium.

  • medium -- The fiber medium.

  • T -- The absolute temperature. \([K]\)

  • sigma_e -- A callable which return the emission cross section. \([nm^2]\) If a callable, the parameters must be the angular frequencies. \([ps^{-1}]\) If none is provided, use fitting formulas.

static calc_sigma(omega, coefficients, lambda_range=None)¶

Calculate the absorption cross section. Calculate with the fitting formula from ref. 1 .

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • coefficients -- The coefficients for the fitting formula. \([\text{factor}, l_c, l_w, n]\)

  • lambda_range -- The range of wavelength in which the fitting formula is valid. (lower_bound, upper_bound)

Returns

Value of the absorption cross section. \([nm^2]\)

Return type

float or numpy.ndarray of float

Notes

Considering:

\[f(\lambda, \lambda_c, \lambda_w, n) = \exp\Big[-\Big\lvert \frac{\lambda-\lambda_c}{\lambda_w}\Big\rvert^n \Big]\]

With \(\lambda\), \(\lambda_c\) and \(\lambda_w\) in \([nm]\)

For Ytterbium:

\[\sigma^{Yb}(\lambda) = 0.09f(\lambda,913,8,2) + 0.13 f(\lambda,950,40,4) + 0.2 f(\lambda, 968, 40, 2.4) + 1.08 f(\lambda, 975.8,3,1.5)\]

For Erbium:

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} \sigma^{Er}(\lambda) &= 0.221 f(\lambda, 1493, 16.5, 2.2) + 0.342 f(\lambda, 1534, 4.5, 1.4)\\ &\quad + 0.158f(\lambda, 1534, 30,4) + 0.037 f(\lambda, 1534, 85, 4) + 0.132 f(\lambda, 1541, 8,0.8) \end{split}\end{split}\]

References

1

Valley, G.C., 2001. Modeling cladding-pumped Er/Yb fiber amplifiers. Optical Fiber Technology, 7(1), pp.21-44.

class optcom.EmissionSection(dopant='yb', medium='sio2', T=293.1, sigma_a=None)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • dopant -- The doping medium.

  • medium -- The fiber medium.

  • T -- The absolute temperature. \([K]\)

  • sigma_a -- A callable which return the absorption cross section. \([nm^2]\) If a callable is provided, the parameters must be the angular frequencies. \([ps^{-1}]\) If none is provided, will construct a parameters.fiber. absorption_section.AbsorptionSection object.

static calc_sigma(omega, sigma_a, T, medium, dopant)¶

Calculate the emission cross section. There is no analytical formula for the emission cross section. Calculate first the absorption cross sections with the fitting formula from ref. 5 and then use the McCumber relations to deduce the emission cross sections.

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • medium -- The type of the doped medium.

  • center_omega -- The center angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • N_0 -- The population in ground state. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • N_1 -- The population in the excited state. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • T -- The temperature. \([K]\)

Returns

Value of the emission cross section. \([nm^2]\)

References

5

Valley, G.C., 2001. Modeling cladding-pumped Er/Yb fiber amplifiers. Optical Fiber Technology, 7(1), pp.21-44.
